questions.text: A 36-year-old obese woman has been experiencing heartburn from gastric reflux for the past 5 years after eating large meals. She undergoes upper gastrointestinal endoscopy, and a biopsy specimen of the distal esophagus is obtained. Which of the following stains shown in the figure can help in making the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Inflammation from reflux of gastric acid has resulted in replacement of normal esophageal squamous epithelium by intestinal-type columnar epithelium with goblet cells.
  • Such conversion of one adult cell type into another cell type is called metaplasia, and it occurs when stimuli reprogram stem cells.
  • These goblet cells contain acidic mucin stained with alcian blue.

Explanation of Other Options:

Toluidine blue(Option A): Used for staining mast cells and nucleic acids; not specific for goblet cells or Barrett esophagus.

PAS (Periodic Acid-Schiff)(Option C): Stains neutral mucins, glycogen, and basement membranes but does not distinguish acidic mucins (from goblet cells) well.

Crystal violet(Option D): Commonly used for amyloid and bacterial cell walls, not for mucins.

choices.text: This is an image of fat necrosis
It occurs when fatty acids are generated that combine with calcium to produce grossly visible chalky-white areas
Deposits of these immune complexes, together with plasma proteins, can cause this
Acute pancreatitis can also show this change due to lipases

questions.text: A 50-year-old female came with a breast lump. On resection, the following was seen. What is not true about the image shown
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fat necrosis refers to focal areas of fat destruction, typically resulting from release of activated pancreatic lipases into the substance of the pancreas and the peritoneal cavity.
  • This occurs in the calamitous abdominal emergency known as acute pancreatitis due to lipases. (Option D ruled out)
  • In this disorder, pancreatic enzymes leak out of damaged acinar cells and liquefy the membranes of fat cells in the peritoneum, releasing triglyceride esters that are split by pancreatic lipases.
  • Fatty acids are generated that combine with calcium to produce grossly visible chalky-white areas(fat saponification), which enable the surgeon and the pathologist to identify the underlying disorder.(Option B ruled out)
  • This type of necrosis is also seen in omentum

questions.text: Which of the following types of cell death is seen in the case of hypoxia in the central nervous system?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Coagulative necrosis is characteristic of infarcts(areas of necrosis caused by ischemia) in all solid organs except the brain.
  • Hypoxia in the CNS (e.g., stroke, infarct) leads to liquefactive necrosis.
  • This is due to the high lipid content and presence of hydrolytic enzymes in brain tissue, which causes rapid enzymatic digestion of tissue, resulting in softening and liquefaction.
  • Microscopically, it shows loss of architecture and numerous neutrophils and debris.

Explanation of Other Options:

Gangrenous necrosis(Option A): Gangrenous necrosis is not a distinct pattern under the microscope; rather, it's a clinical term used for large areas of ischemic necrosis typically in limbs (like in diabetic foot or severe trauma).

Fat necrosis(Option B): Fat necrosis involves enzymatic digestion of fat, typically seen in acute pancreatitis or trauma to fatty tissue (like breast or subcutaneous fat).

questions.text: Identify the morphological appearance of the arrow in the figure below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In H&E-stained tissue sections, the nuclei of apoptotic cells exhibit various stages of chromatin condensation and aggregation, ultimately leading to karyorrhexis.
  • At the molecular level, this is reflected in the fragmentation of DNA into nucleosome-sized pieces.
  • The cells rapidly shrink, form cytoplasmic buds, and fragment into apoptotic bodies that are composed of membrane-bound pieces of cytosol and organelles.
  • Because these fragments are quickly extruded and phagocytosed without eliciting an inflammatory response, even substantial apoptosis may be histologically undetectable.

Explanation of Other Options:

Condensation of chromatin(Option A): This refers to the early stage of apoptosis, where the nuclear chromatin becomes densely packed and dark-staining, typically appearing as a shrunken, intensely basophilic nucleus. However, it does not result in the formation of discrete membrane-bound fragments, known as apoptotic bodies.

Membrane blebs(Option B): Membrane blebs are bubble-like protrusions of the cell membrane that occur during early apoptosis; they precede the formation of apoptotic bodies, but blebs are not yet detached or fragmented, so they do not match the image showing separated structures.

Normal cell(Option C): A normal cell has an intact nucleus and cytoplasm with no membrane blebbing or fragmentation; since the image shows fragmented cell parts, this option is incorrect for identifying apoptotic bodies.

questions.text: Deficiency or excess of which of the following vitamins induces squamous metaplasia in the respiratory epithelium?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Vitamin A is essential for normal epithelial differentiation.
  • Its deficiency may also induce squamous metaplasia in the respiratory epithelium.
  • This makes the epithelium less functional, especially in mucous production and ciliary action, increasing the risk of respiratory infections.

Explanation of Other Options:

Ascorbic acid (Option A): Deficiency causes scurvy, leading to defective collagen synthesis, gum bleeding, and poor wound healing, not squamous metaplasia.

Cholecalciferol (Option C): Involved in calcium and phosphate metabolism. Deficiency leads to rickets or osteomalacia, not epithelial changes.

Citric acid(Option D): It is an intermediate in the Krebs cycle, not a vitamin. It does not play a role in epithelial differentiation or squamous metaplasia.

questions.text: Clearance of apoptotic cells by professional and nonprofessional phagocytes is called
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Apoptotic bodies may also become coated with natural antibodies and proteins of the complement system, notably C1q, which are recognized by phagocytes.

Thus, numerous ligands induced on apoptotic cells serve as ''eat me" signals and are recognized by receptors on phagocytes that bind and engulf these cells.

This process of apoptotic cell phagocytosis is called efferocytosis; it is so efficient that dead cells disappear, often within minutes, without leaving a trace.

Explanation of Other Options:

Pyroptosis: A highly inflammatory form of programmed cell death, typically triggered by infections. Mediated by caspase-1 and associated with the release of IL-1β and IL-18.

Pinocytosis: A form of endocytosis where the cell engulfs fluids and solutes, often referred to as cell drinking.

Necroptosis: A programmed form of necrosis, combining features of both necrosis and apoptosis. Involves RIPK1, RIPK3, and MLKL signaling. It is inflammatory and occurs when caspase-8 is inhibited.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about necroptosis is not true
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Necroptosis is a caspase-independent process
  • Morphologically resembles necrosis, but the mechanism is like apoptosis

questions.text: Annexin V is associated with?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Annexin A5 (or annexin V) is a cellular protein in the annexin group.
  • The function of the protein is unknown; however, annexin A5 has been proposed to play a role in the inhibition of blood coagulation by competing for phosphatidylserine binding sites with prothrombin and also to inhibit the activity of phospholipase A1 Antibodies directed against annexin A5 are found in patients with a disease called the antiphospholipid syndrome (APS), a thrombophilic disease associated with autoantibodies against phospholipid compounds.
  • Annexin A5 is used as a probe in the annexin A5 affinity assay to detect cells that have expressed phosphatidylserine on the cell surface, a feature found in apoptosis as well as other forms of cell death
  • Annexin V is used in flow cytometry to detect apoptotic cells.

Explanation of Other Options:

Necrosis(Options A):

  • Necrosis involves membrane rupture and uncontrolled cell lysis.
  • There is no phosphatidylserine flipping specific to early necrosis.
  • Annexin V is not a marker for necrosis, though necrotic cells may bind Annexin V late due to membrane disruption - but this is not specific.

Atherosclerosis(Option B):

  • Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease involving lipid accumulation and macrophages.
  • Though apoptosis occurs in atherosclerosis, Annexin V is not directly associated as a diagnostic or characteristic marker for the disease.

Inflammation(Option D):

  • Inflammation is a response to injury or infection.
  • Apoptosis is typically non-inflammatory, whereas necrosis induces inflammation.
  • Annexin V does not mark inflammation directly.

choices.text: Only I, II, and III are correct
Only I and III are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
What is/are true about metastatic calcification in the following sentences?
i. Lungs and kidneys are commonly affected.
ii. Occurs in damaged heart valves.
iii. Serum calcium levels are high
iv. Occurs in dead/dying tissue
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Metastatic calcification: This form is associated with hypercalcemia and can occur in normal tissues(Statement III). The major causes of hypercalcemia are

  • Increased secretion of parathyroid hormone, due to either primary parathyroid tumors or production of parathyroid hormone-related protein by other malignant tumors
  • Destruction of bone due to the effects of accelerated turnover(e.g., Paget disease), immobilization, or tumors (increased bone catabolism associated with multiple myeloma, leukemia, or diffuse skeletal metastases)
  • Vitamin D-D-related disorders, including vitamin D intoxication and sarcoidosis(in which macrophages activate a vitamin D precursor)
  • Renal failure, in which phosphate retention leads to secondary hyperparathyroidism.
  • Metastatic calcification tends to occur in organs that lose acid quickly, i.e., those that excrete acid and have an alkaline environment: lungs, kidneys, gastric mucosa, and systemic arteries. These alkaline environments favor calcium salt precipitation.(Statement I)

questions.text: A 30-year-old female's ultrasonography reveals a 6x5 cm mass in the right ovary. Histologic sections from this ovarian mass reveal a papillary tumour with multiple, scattered small, round, laminated calcifications. What is a type of cell injury in the laminated structure present in a tumour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Psammoma Bodies and Dystrophic Calcification:

  • Psammoma bodies are lamellated configurations resembling grains of sand.
  • They are formed through the progressive acquisition of outer layers.
  • Dystrophic calcification is a type of cell injury characterized by the deposition of calcium salts.
  • It occurs in damaged or dying tissues.
  • Psammoma bodies are a hallmark of dystrophic calcification.
  • Dystrophic calcification happens locally, often in areas of tissue damage or inflammation.
  • This occurs despite normal serum levels of calcium and without disturbances in calcium metabolism.

Explanation of Other Options:

Apoptosis(Option A):

  • Apoptosis is a programmed cell death process.
  • It does not involve the deposition of calcium salts.
  • It is a highly regulated mechanism of cell death that occurs in a controlled manner.
  • It does not result in the formation of calcifications.

Enzymatic Necrosis(Option C):

  • Enzymatic necrosis is a type of cell death resulting from the release of enzymes from damaged cells.
  • While enzymatic processes can contribute to tissue damage and inflammation, they do not lead to the formation of calcifications.
  • Enzymatic necrosis typically involves the digestion of cellular components.

Metastatic Calcification(Option D):

  • Metastatic calcification is a type of calcification that occurs in otherwise normal tissues.
  • It results from systemic factors, particularly hypercalcemia.
  • It affects various tissues throughout the body, including blood vessels, kidneys, and lungs.
  • In the described case, calcifications are localized within the ovarian tumor, making metastatic calcification unlikely.

Common Cancers Associated with Psammoma Bodies:

  • M:Meningioma, Mesothelioma
  • O:Papillary carcinoma of the Ovary
  • S:Papillary carcinoma of the salivary gland
  • T:Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid
  • P:Prolactinoma
  • G:Glucagonoma

choices.text: A, B and C are true, D is false
A, B and D are true, C is false
A, C and D are true, B is false

questions.text:
Mark the correct answers about autophagy.
A. Crohn's and ulcerative colitis are linked to SNPs in autophagy-related genes
B. Mycobacteria, Shigella spp., and HSV-1 impair autophagy
C. In Alzheimer's disease, formation of autophagosomes is retarded.
D. In Huntington disease, mutant huntingtin impairs autophagy
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In Alzheimer's disease, autophagosome formation is actually accelerated, not retarded, but the problem lies in their clearance.

Crohn's and ulcerative colitis are linked to SNPs in autophagy-related genes(Statement A):

  • Polymorphisms in autophagy genes such as ATG16L1 and IRGM are strongly associated with Crohn's disease.
  • These SNPs affect bacterial clearance and immune regulation.
  • Similar, though less strong, links are observed in ulcerative colitis.

Mycobacteria, Shigella spp., and HSV-1 impair autophagy(Statement B):

  • These pathogens have evolved mechanisms to evade or inhibit autophagy, helping them survive intracellularly.
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis inhibits autophagosome maturation.
  • Shigella secretes proteins that block autophagosome formation.
  • HSV-1 encodes 5, which inhibits autophagy by blocking Beclin-1.

In Alzheimer's disease, formation of autophagosomes is retarded(Statement C):

  • Autophagosome formation is increased (accelerated), possibly as a response to accumulating protein aggregates (like amyloid-β and tau).
  • However, autophagosome maturation and degradation (fusion with lysosomes) is impaired.
  • As a result, autophagic vacuoles accumulate in neurons, particularly in dystrophic neurites.

In Huntington disease, mutant huntingtin impairs autophagy(Statement D):

  • The mutant huntingtin protein (mHtt) interferes with the recognition of cargo during autophagy.
  • This leads to ineffective degradation of damaged proteins and organelles.
  • Autophagy dysfunction contributes to neuronal death.

questions.text: Identify the morphological change in the figure below:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hydropic change refers to the accumulation of water within the cytoplasm of a cell, also known as cloudy swelling, and is a morphological feature of reversible cell injury.

Hydropic Degeneration, which is a type of reversible cell injury characterized by:

  • Cellular swelling due to failure of ATP-dependent Na+/K+ pumps, leading to influx of sodium and water.
  • Cytoplasm appears vacuolated or clear under the microscope due to accumulation of water.
  • Commonly seen in renal tubular epithelial cells, liver, and myocardium

Explanation of Other Options:

Fatty Degeneration(Option A): Involves lipid accumulation in the cytoplasm, often in liver cells (hepatic steatosis). Appears as large, clear fat vacuoles pushing the nucleus to the periphery.

Mucinous Degeneration(Option B): Accumulation of mucin (glycoproteins) often seen in epithelial tumors or connective tissues, giving a gelatinous appearance.

Hyaline Degeneration(Option C): Involves homogeneous, glassy, eosinophilic appearance due to accumulation of proteins, seen in conditions like arteriosclerosis or glomerular disease.

choices.text: LC3 is a marker of autophagy
Mammalian target of rapamycin stimulates autophagy

questions.text: Not true about autophagy
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin) is a negative regulator of autophagy.
  • When nutrients and growth factors are abundant, mTOR is active, and it inhibits autophagy.
  • In nutrient deprivation or stress, mTOR is inhibited, which allows autophagy to be initiated.

Explanation of Other Options:

LC3 is a marker of autophagy(Option A): LC3-I (cytosolic form) gets conjugated to phosphatidylethanolamine to become LC3-II, which is membrane-bound and integrates into the autophagosomal membrane.

Initiation by ULK1/2 complexes(Option B): ULK1/2 complex (Unc-51-like kinase) is crucial in initiating autophagy, especially in response to nutrient deprivation.

It is negatively regulated by mTOR.

Nucleation by Beclin-1 core complexes(Option C): Beclin-1 associates with class III PI3K (Vps34) to form a nucleation complex that drives phagophore formation, a critical step in autophagosome biogenesis.

questions.text: Russell's bodies, which are round eosinophilic inclusions found in plasma cells in multiple myeloma, are due to the accumulation of which substance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In multiple myeloma, the marked accumulation of newly synthesized immunoglobulins may occur in the RER of some plasma cells, forming rounded, eosinophilic Russell bodies.
  • Cells may accumulate abnormal amounts of various substances, which may be harmless or may cause varying degrees of injury.
  • The substance may be located in the cytoplasm, within organelles(typically lysosomes), or in the nucleus, and it may be synthesized by the affected cells or it may be produced elsewhere.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Polysaccharides(Option B): These are carbohydrate-based and do not form Russell bodies.
  • Lipids(Option C): Accumulated lipids form different inclusions (like lipid droplets or foam cells).
  • Cholesterol esters(Option D): Seen in atherosclerosis and xanthomas, not in Russell bodies.

questions.text: The given figure shows lipofuscin granules in cardiomyocytes. Name the condition
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pigments are colored substances that are either exogenous, coming from outside the body, such as carbon, or are endogenous, synthesized within the body itself, such as lipofuscin, melanin, and certain derivatives of hemoglobin.

Lipofuscin:

  • Lipofuscin is a yellow-brown, finely granular intracellular pigment.
  • It is composed of lipid-containing residues of lysosomal digestion (partially degraded membranes and proteins).
  • Found especially in long-lived cells like cardiac myocytes, neurons, hepatocytes, and retinal pigment epithelium.
  • Seen in brown atrophy of the heart.
  • More prominent in conditions of malnutrition, cachexia, or chronic disease.
  • Not associated with cell death, but indicates past injury and autophagic activity.
  • Lipofuscin is often called the wear-and-tear pigment

choices.text: Only I, II, and III are correct
Only I and III are correct
Only II and IV are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions shows Mallory Hyaline bodies?
I. Hepatocellular Carcinoma
II. Primary Biliary Cirrhosis
III. Alcoholic Liver Cirrhosis
IV. Hemochromatosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mallory hyaline bodies (also called Mallory-Denk bodies) are abnormal, eosinophilic (pink-staining), rope-like cytoplasmic inclusions found within hepatocytes. They are composed mainly of damaged intermediate filaments, especially cytokeratin 8 and 18.

Conditions Associated with Mallory Hyaline Bodies:

  • Alcoholic Hepatitis
    • Most classic and common association
    • Chronic alcohol use damages hepatocytes → Mallory body formation
  • Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis (NASH)
    • Seen in obesity, diabetes, metabolic syndrome
    • Similar histologic injury to alcoholic hepatitis
  • Wilson's Disease
    • Genetic disorder of copper metabolism
    • Copper accumulation leads to hepatocyte injury and Mallory body formation
  • Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC)
    • Autoimmune destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts
    • Associated with hepatocyte injury and Mallory body formation
  • Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC)
    • Progressive inflammation and fibrosis of bile ducts
    • Can also show Mallory bodies, though less commonly
  • Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC)
    • Some tumors show Mallory bodies within malignant hepatocytes
  • Chronic Cholestatic Conditions
    • Long-standing obstruction or bile duct disease may lead to Mallory body development
  • Indian Childhood Cirrhosis
    • Copper-associated liver disease in infants
    • Rare, but can exhibit Mallory hyaline
  • Other Cirrhotic States
    • In advanced cirrhosis from various causes, especially when hepatocytes are under stress

choices.text: Both statements are true and causally related
Both statements are true but not causally related
The first statement is true, and the second is false
The first statement is false, and the second is true

questions.text:
Assertion: The most common exogenous pigment is carbon.
Reason: The most common endogenous pigment is lipofuscin.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pigments are colored substances that are either exogenous, coming from outside the body, such as carbon, or are endogenous, synthesized within the body itself, such as lipofuscin, melanin, and certain derivatives of hemoglobin.

questions.text: Principle of Prussian blue stain:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Prussian blue stain detects ferric iron (Fe³+) in tissues, typically in the form of hemosiderin.
  • Potassium ferrocyanide reacts with ferric ions (Fe³+) in acidic medium to form insoluble ferric ferrocyanide also called Prussian blue, which appears as deep blue granules under the microscope.

Ferric iron (Fe³+) + Potassium ferrocyanide → Ferric ferrocyanide (Prussian blue)

  • It does not detect ferrous iron (Fe²+).
  • Commonly used to diagnose hemochromatosis, hemosiderosis, or assess iron overload in organs.
  • Stains iron in blue, counterstains tissue in pink (nuclear fast red).

questions.text: A 50-year-old female underwent cholecystectomy. On examination, the lamina propria of the gall bladder was seen to be infiltrated by foam cells. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cholesterolosis refers to the accumulation of cholesterol-laden macrophages (foam cells) in the lamina propria of the gallbladder mucosa.
  • It is sometimes called "strawberry gallbladder" due to the yellow speckled appearance of cholesterol deposits against a red mucosal background.
  • Seen in middle-aged females, often discovered incidentally during cholecystectomy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Atherosclerosis(Option B): Foam cells are present, but in arterial intima, not gallbladder.

Steatosis(Option C): Refers to fat accumulation in hepatocytes, seen in the liver, not the gallbladder.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male labourer consulted a doctor because he noticed yellow discoloration of the sclera and also gave a history of passing yellow urine for a few days. He was advised to complete blood counts, and liver function tests; a liver biopsy was undertaken. The liver biopsy shows yellowish brown pigment on H & E stain. Which of the following is the most likely pigment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The condition reflects Jaundice with Hyperbilirubinemia.
  • Bilirubin is the normal non-iron-containing pigment present in the bile.

Explanation of Other Options:

Melanin pigment(Option A): Appears brown-black, usually found in skin, basal ganglia, and melanomas not associated with liver pathology or jaundice.

Homogentisic acid pigment(Option C): Seen in alkaptonuria; leads to ochronosis (black-blue pigmentation of connective tissue), not relevant in liver or jaundice.

Porphyrin pigments(Option D): Involved in porphyrias leads to photosensitivity and red urine, not yellow discoloration of sclera or liver pigment changes.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male died in a road traffic accident. He had no significant medical history apart from his occupational history as a mining supervisor in Coal India. Autopsy and subsequent histopathological examination of his lung biopsy on H & E stain are seen in the picture below. Identify the black coloured pigment noted with blue arrows.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Anthracosis is the deposition of carbon particles.
  • Extensive deposition causes pneumoconiosis.
  • It is an example of exogenous pigment deposition.
  • The patient has an occupational history.

Explanation of Other Options:

Melanin pigment(Option A): Brown-black pigment, seen in melanocytes, melanomas, or basal ganglia, not in lungs due to environmental exposure.

Hemosiderin pigment(Option B): Golden-yellow to brown pigment, seen in chronic pulmonary congestion, hemosiderosis, and hemorrhage, stains blue with Prussian blue, not black on H&E.

Formalin pigment(Option D): Artifact seen when tissue is fixed in acidic formalin, appears brown-black, but it's rare and does not localize to lung macrophages systematically.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male had a history of hepatitis B infection. On liver biopsy, multiple councilman bodies were seen. Electrophoresis was done to determine whether he was undergoing apoptosis or necrosis. Identify the pattern in lane 2 and the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a step ladder pattern which is typically seen in apoptosis. It's also called DNA laddering, characterized by the activation of endogenous endonucleases with subsequent cleavage of chromatin DNA into internucleosomal fragments of roughly 180-200 base pairs(bp).
  • A smear pattern is seen in necrosis.

questions.text: True regarding sirtuin functions
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sirutins:

  • These include proteins that inhibit metabolic activity, reduce apoptosis, stimulate protein folding, inhibit the harmful effects of oxygen free radicals, and activate DNA repair enzymes through deacylation
  • Sirtuins (also spelled Sir2 proteins) are a family of NAD+-dependent deacetylases and ADP-ribosyltransferases that play key roles in cellular regulation, metabolism, aging, and stress resistance.

Functions of Sirtuins:

  • Regulation of Gene Expression:
    • Sirtuins deacetylate histones and transcription factors (like p53, NF-κB, FOXO) → alters gene expression.
  • DNA Repair:
    • Especially SIRT6 and SIRT1 help in DNA repair and genome stability.
  • Metabolism:
    • Mitochondrial sirtuins (SIRT3, SIRT4, SIRT5) regulate oxidative metabolism, fatty acid oxidation, and urea cycle.
  • Aging and Longevity:
    • Sirtuins are activated during caloric restriction and are thought to extend lifespan by reducing oxidative stress and improving metabolic efficiency.
  • Stress Response and Apoptosis:
    • Sirtuins regulate survival pathways, reduce oxidative stress, and modulate apoptosis (e.g., SIRT1 deacetylates p53 to suppress apoptosis).
  • Inflammation:
    • SIRT1 inhibits NF-κB, a key player in the inflammatory response.

questions.text: Syndrome caused due to defective DNA helicase
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Werner Syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder that causes premature aging. It's also known as adult progeria.

WRN gene mutation → defective DNA helicase

Leads to:

  • Defective DNA repair
  • Telomere shortening
  • Genomic instability
  • Accelerated cell senescence

Explanation of Other Options:

Down syndrome(Option A): Down syndrome is a chromosomal disorder caused by trisomy 21, resulting from nondisjunction, and is not related to defects in DNA helicase.

Wermer syndrome(Option C): Wermer syndrome, also known as Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN1), is caused by mutations in the MEN1 gene, and involves tumors of the parathyroid, pancreas, and pituitary, with no association with DNA helicase.

Turner syndrome(Option D): Turner syndrome is a monosomy disorder (45,X) affecting females, characterized by short stature and gonadal dysgenesis, and it is not linked to DNA helicase defects.

questions.text: Which concept states that a normal human cell can only replicate and divide forty to sixty times before it cannot divide anymore, and will break down by programmed cell death or apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hayflick limit concept describes the phenomenon where normal human somatic cells can divide only 40-60 times in culture due to the progressive shortening of telomeres with each division.
  • Once this limit is reached, cells enter senescence and eventually die via apoptosis. This is a key mechanism in aging and tumor suppression.

Explanation of Other Options:

Gompertzian Phenomenon(Option B): This refers to the exponential increase in mortality with age, and in cancer biology, it describes tumor growth curves that slow as the tumor increases in size-not related to the finite number of cell divisions.

Oncogene Addiction(Option C): This is a concept in cancer biology where tumor cells become heavily dependent on a single overactive oncogene for survival and proliferation. Targeting that oncogene can cause tumor regression, but it's unrelated to natural cell division limits.

Sigma Graph(Option D): This term is not a recognized biological or cellular concept in the context of programmed cell death or replication limits. It may refer generically to an S-shaped (sigmoid) curve used in statistics or pharmacology.

choices.text: Both statements are true and causally related
Both statements are true, but not causally related
The first statement is true, the second is false
The first statement is false, and the second is true

questions.text:
Assertion: Replicative senescence occurs in aging cells.
Reason: Progressive shortening of telomeres results in cell cycle arrest.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • With aging, many cells enter a state called replicative senescence, where they lose the ability to divide further.
  • Each time a cell divides, its telomeres (protective caps at the ends of chromosomes) shorten.
  • Eventually, when they become critically short, the cell recognizes this as DNA damage and activates p53 and Rb pathways, leading to permanent cell cycle arrest (senescence).
